title: 114_hr1955
content: The "Great Lakes Nutrient Removal Assistance Act" aims to address water pollution in the Great Lakes System by focusing on nutrient pollution, particularly phosphorus loading. The Act emphasizes the importance of limiting phosphorus loads to control algal growth and highlights nutrient removal technology as an effective method for reducing harmful nutrients from point sources. Section 118 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to establish a Nutrient Removal Technology Grant Program for Great Lakes States and municipalities to install technologies reducing nutrients in wastewater. The Administrator shall give priority to eligible facilities for nutrient removal technologies based on load reductions, environmental benefits to the Great Lakes System, and meeting nutrient objectives outlined in Annex 4 of the Great Lakes Water Quality Protocol of 2012. The Administrator may approve grant applications for nutrient removal technologies in Great Lakes States or municipalities, providing up to 55% of the installation cost at eligible facilities. Application details are to be prescribed by the Administrator. The Administrator may approve grant applications for nutrient removal technologies in Great Lakes States or municipalities, covering up to 55% of installation costs at eligible facilities with a design capacity to treat at least 500,000 gallons annually. Additionally, there is authorized funding of $100,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2016 to 2020 for this purpose. The Administrator may use up to 4 percent of available funds to cover administrative costs for implementing the subsection.
